Gram-Schmidt process

We actually normalize the vectors too

$v_1 = \frac{u_1}{\lvert u_1 \rvert}$
$u^{\perp}_2 = u_2 - \frac{u_2 \cdot v_1}{{\lvert v_1 \rvert}^2}v_1 = u_2 - (u_2 \cdot v_1)v_1$
$v_2 = \frac{u^{\perp}_2}{\lvert u^{\perp}_2 \rvert}$
$v_3 = u_3 - c_1v_1 - c_2v_2 = \dots$

How to pick $c_1, c_2$...
It's a system of equations that gives us
$c_1 = u_3 \cdot v_1$
$c_2 = u_3 \cdot v_2$

So $u^{\perp}_3 = u_3 - (u_3 \cdot v_1)v_1 - (u_3 \cdot v_2)v_2$
$v_3 = \frac{u^{\perp}_3}{\lvert u^{\perp}_3 \rvert}$

We can prove that the subspace doesn't change by stating these definitions as elementary row operations

$QR$ factorization is a factorization of $A$ with $Q$ unit orthogonal ($QQ^{-1} = QQ^T = I$) and $R$ upper triangular

$r_{11} = \lvert u_1 \rvert$
$u_1 = r_{11} v_1$
$r_{12} = v_1 \cdot u_2$
$r_{22} = \lvert u^{\perp}_2 \rvert$
$u_2 = r_{12}v_1 + r_{22}v_2$
$r_{13} = v_1 \cdot u_3$
$r_{23} = v_2 \cdot u_3$
$r_{33} = \lvert u^{\perp}_3 \rvert$
$u_3 = r_{13}v_1 + r_{23}v_2 + r_{33}v_3$

$R = \matrixstart r_{11} & r_{12} & r_{13} \\ 0 & r_{22} & r_{23} \\ 0 & 0 & r_{33} \matrixend$

Uses?

To project $x$ into the subspace given by the orthonormal basis, we compute a linear combination of $v_i$
$(v_1 \cdot x)v_1 + (v_2 \cdot x)v_2 + (v_3 \cdot x)v_3$
That is, the coordinate of the projection is $\matrixstart v_1 \cdot x \\ v_2 \cdot x \\ v_3 \cdot x \matrixend$
AND the actual vector is of course $\matrixstart v_1 & v_2 & v_3 \matrixend \matrixstart v_1 \cdot x \\ v_2 \cdot x \\ v_3 \cdot x \matrixend$
This is $Q\matrixstart v_1 \cdot x \\ v_2 \cdot x \\ v_3 \cdot x \matrixend = QQ^Tx = x?$
